Rather than disappear from the battlefield, the Sentinel now began to appear in increasing numbers thanks to ComStar and its massive stockpile of SLDF material, both providing the design to the Draconis Combine prior to the War of 3039 and using it to help outfit its Com Guards. Quirk: Improved Communications Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.02

Arm Actuator Limit: Left Upper

name: Sentry SNT-04
details: The Sentry was developed under pressure from the Draconis and Capellan marches for a more advanced 'Mech to defend the borders of the Federated Suns. The 'Mech is built on a light weight Dorwinion hyperactive 3 Endo Steel chassis. This chassis saves weight, allowing the 'Mech to carry heavier weapons and equipment. The Sentry is powered by a Nissan 200 fusion engine that gives it a top speed of 86.4 km/h that is augmented by five HildCo Model 12 jump jets that make it possible for the Sentry to jump up to one hundred and fifty meters. To compensate for its less than average mobility, the Sentry has an impressive eight and a half tons of Starshield A armor that has been fitted with CASE to protect the 'Mech from an ammunition explosion. Quirk: Easy to Pilot Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.02

name: Shadow Cat A
details:
The Shadow Cat is a heavily-armed and maneuverable medium OmniMech developed by Clan Nova Cat to replace the Ice Ferret in the early 31st century during preparations for Operation Revival. The first alternate configuration is also potent at long range, but it uses a pair of ER Large Lasers to gain that potency. It retains the Active Probe of the prime, but uses a Streak SRM-6 for backup. It also utilizes three extra double heat sinks to keep heat levels comfortable. Quirk: Narrow/Low Profile Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.04

Arm Actuator Limits: Omni

name: Shadow Cat B
details:
The Shadow Cat is a heavily-armed and maneuverable medium OmniMech developed by Clan Nova Cat to replace the Ice Ferret in the early 31st century during preparations for Operation Revival. The B variant is also a fusion of long-range weaponry with a scouting system. This configuration adds a pair of Artemis IV-guided LRM 15s to the Active Probe. It also has a pair of ER Medium Lasers for backup, though it adds an ECM Suite to the electronics package. Quirk: Narrow/Low Profile Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.04

Arm Actuator Limits: Omni

name: Shadow Cat C
details:
The Shadow Cat is a heavily-armed and maneuverable medium OmniMech developed by Clan Nova Cat to replace the Ice Ferret in the early 31st century during preparations for Operation Revival. A more recent variant, the Shadow Cat C marries a pair of ATM 6s to three ER Medium Lasers. It mounts enough ammunition to make use of the flexibility of the Advanced Tactical Missile System. A Narc Missile Beacon helps Starmates' missiles target an enemy unit. Quirk: Narrow/Low Profile Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.04

Arm Actuator Limits: Omni

name: Shadow Cat M
details:
The Shadow Cat is a heavily-armed and maneuverable medium OmniMech developed by Clan Nova Cat to replace the Ice Ferret in the early 31st century during preparations for Operation Revival. The SHC-M configuration boasts a full energy loadout featuring a Large Pulse Laser in each arm and a pair of ER Medium Lasers. Quirk: Narrow/Low Profile Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.04

Arm Actuator Limits: Omni

name: Shadow Cat Prime
details:
The Shadow Cat is a heavily-armed and maneuverable medium OmniMech developed by Clan Nova Cat to replace the Ice Ferret in the early 31st century during preparations for Operation Revival. The primary configuration of the Shadow Cat wields a Gauss Rifle allowing it to handily defeat smaller opponents, often before they can get within range. A pair of smaller ER Medium Lasers back up the rifle, and an Active Probe gives the Shadow Cat the ability to detect hidden units, making it a capable scout. Quirk: Narrow/Low Profile Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.04

Arm Actuator Limits: Omni

name: Shadow Cat TC
details:
A 45 ton Clan OmniMech, the Shadow Cat was designed as a replacement for the Ice Ferret. Debuting in 3003, the OmniMech is powered by a 270-rated XL Engine with a combination of Endo Steel and Ferro-Fibrous providing the free weight for 17 tons of pod space. 6 Jump Jets and MASC are hardwired to the chassis, enhancing it’s mobility. The Shadow Cat TC was originally a custom variant, but made a name for itself on Tukayyid; fighting against the massed tanks and infantry of the Comguard. An LB-10X, supported by a pair of Small Pulse Lasers and an SRM-4 make up the TC’s weapons, while an Active Probe allows the TC to scout enemy positions. Quirk: Narrow/Low Profile Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.04

Arm Actuator Limits: Omni

name: Shadow Cat U
details:
The U loadout drops both the MASC and the Jump Jets, which allows the 'Mech to carry more armor and better cooling. The mounted weapons are two Large Pulse Lasers and two ER Medium Lasers. To save costs the chassis is also downgraded to standard specification instead of using Endo Steel. Quirk: Narrow/Low Profile Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.04

Arm Actuator Limits: Omni

name: Shadow Cat V
details:
The V configuration mounts two Large Pulse Laser and two ER Medium Lasers, making it an all energy weapon build. To handle the increased heat three additional double heat sinks were added, but in turn dropped the MASC and carries no equipment for electronic warfare. Quirk: Narrow/Low Profile Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.04

Arm Actuator Limits: Omni

name: Shadow Cat W
details:
The W loadout removes the Jump Jets of the primary configuration. This allows the use of three Large Pulse Lasers as the main armament of the 'Mech, with three additional heat sinks to deal with the heat build-up. Quirk: Narrow/Low Profile Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.04

Arm Actuator Limits: Omni

name: Shadow Cat X
details:
The X loadout is used when a formal battle challenge, more commonly knows as a batchall, is used. Since the Gauss rifle of the primary configuration is too unwieldy during such combat a LBX/5 autocannon is used instead, accompanied by a Large Pulse Laser and two SRM-4 launchers. Quirk: Narrow/Low Profile Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.04

Arm Actuator Limits: Omni

name: Shadow Hawk IIC 1
details: The Shadow Hawk IIC is a second-line Clan BattleMech based upon the Shadow Hawk that was first fielded by the Star League. The first version of the Shadow Hawk IIC is meant for close-range fighting, and appears to be designed with urban warfare in mind. It is armed with a Medium Pulse Laser in each arm, two Streak SRM-2 launchers in each side torso, an ER Medium Laser in the head, and an ER Small Laser in the torso. Ten double heat sinks take care of most heat, especially since the Streaks will build no heat if they do not achieve a lock and fire. Quirk: Battle Fists Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.07

name: Shadow Hawk IIC 2
details: The Shadow Hawk IIC is a second-line Clan BattleMech based upon the Shadow Hawk that was first fielded by the Star League. The second variant is designed for long-range, direct-fire support using two ER Large Lasers as its primary weapons. The ER Small Laser is retained and supplemented by three Small Pulse Lasers for close in work. Quirk: Battle Fists Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.07

name: Shadow Hawk IIC 3
details: The Shadow Hawk IIC is a second-line Clan BattleMech based upon the Shadow Hawk that was first fielded by the Star League. A newer variant that dates to the late 3050s, the IIC 3's primary weapon is a Heavy Large Laser, supplemented by a Medium Pulse Laser. The 'Mech carries paired ER Micro Lasers and Micro Pulse Lasers should it find itself in a close range fight. Four additional double heat sinks keep down the heat generated by the all-laser complement. Quirk: Battle Fists Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.09

name: Shadow Hawk IIC 4
details: The Shadow Hawk IIC is a second-line Clan BattleMech based upon the Shadow Hawk that was first fielded by the Star League. First fielded in 3060, the IIC 4 was a joint effort by Clan Nova Cat and Clan Diamond Shark to upgrade their second-line forces. The result was a 'Mech that is visually very different from the design it is considered a variant of. This 'Mech carries a ATM 6 System with three tons of varied ammunition to allow for flexibility of choice. The missile launcher is backed up by two Medium Pulse Lasers and an ER Medium Laser. Quirk: Battle Fists Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.07

name: Shadow Hawk LAM SHD-X1
details: The original and considerably flawed prototypes were completed in 2680. Based on the Shadow Hawk SHD-2H, the 'Mech carried a Class 2 Autocannon in place of the Class 5. The SHD-X1 carried only 6.5 tons of armor for protection. Only one chassis survived multiple crashes caused by its faulty schematics. It had a top ground speed of 86.4 km/h like its progenitor, the SHD-2H, and used ten single heat sinks. Field refits to increase firepower with wing-mounted weapons were common, but often caused more problems than they solved. Quirk: Land Air Mech Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.05

name: Shadow Hawk LAM SHD-X2
details: Allied Aerospace won the SLDF's contract to produce a series of Land-Air mechs with a design based on the venerable Shadow HawkBattleMech. Allied gave their new Land-Air 'Mech the ability to convert directly into an Aerospace Fighter. While construction was completed in 2680, thanks to the chassis' numerous flaws, lackluster performance and a number of ill-fated and publicly witnessed test-flights disasters during SLDF reviews in 2682, Allied Aerospace was forced to go back to the drawing board. The more refined X2 variant faced considerable scrutiny by SLDF evaluators in 2684, successfully meeting the SLDF's requirements but still rejected thanks to its high fuel consumption and the bad press generated by the earlier X1. Twenty SHD-X2 were built for trials with potential customers, but failed to attract any interest. Ultimately Allied scrapped the Shadow Hawk LAM program in favor of what became the considerably more successful Phoenix Hawk LAM. Quirk: Land Air Mech Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.05

name: Shadow Hawk LAM SHD-X3
details: The original and considerably flawed prototypes were completed in 2680. Based on the Shadow Hawk SHD-2H, the 'Mech carried a Pair of SRM-6 Valiant in place of the Class 5 Autocannon. The SHD-X3 carried only 6.5 tons of armor for protection. Only one chassis survived multiple crashes caused by its faulty schematics. It had a top ground speed of 86.4 km/h like its progenitor, the SHD-2H, and used ten single heat sinks. Field refits to increase firepower with wing-mounted weapons were common, but often caused more problems than they solved. Quirk: Land Air Mech Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.05

name: REPORT ME REP-ME
details: BRING THE LOG TO DISCORD SO WE CAN FIX THIS APPEARING OR GET REKTED AGAIN!

name: Shadow Hawk SHD-1P
details: Introduced in 3024, this variant of the Shadow Hawk drops the SHD-2H's SRM-2 rack to free up the weight for a medium claw fitted in the SHD-1P's left arm. Quirk: Battle Fists Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.03

name: Shadow Hawk SHD-1R
details: First introduced in 2467, this first generation of the Shadow Hawk employs early BattleMech technology in its weaponry, equipment and its armor. This design was first produced by Lang Industries on Caph, where it was designed as part of the Hegemony's efforts to keep ahead of the Inner Sphere's newly stolen BattleMech technology. Quirk: Battle Fists Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.82

name: Shadow Hawk SHD-2D
details: The Shadow Hawk 2D is an interesting model. Its default payload sacrifices a lot of armor to mount a bit more firepower, though some argue the tradeoff isn't worth it. Its Alpha Strikes are better, though, so I guess you can be the judge of its worth. Quirk: Battle Fists Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.03

name: Shadow Hawk SHD-2D2
details: The 2D2 is an upgrade of the -2D Shadow Hawk introduced in 3049, born of the Federated Commonwealth buying original-model 2Hs from Majesty Metals and refitting them for use by militia forces or for sale to mercenaries. Like the 2D this upgrade adds another SRM launcher to the center torso and a medium laser to the left arm, however both center torso and head launchers are Federated SuperStreak Streak SRM-2s. Besides carrying slightly more armor, a total of six and a half tons, and one ton of Streak ammo in the right torso, it is otherwise identical to the 2D Shadow Hawk. Quirk: Battle Fists Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.03

name: Shadow Hawk SHD-2GD
details: A heavily modified variant of the Shadow Hawk, using Clan tech to improve its performance greatly. Originally conceptualized by Grey Death Legion, the variant has seen some spread to other mercenaries as well. Quirk: Battle Fists Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.11

name: Shadow Hawk SHD-2H
details: The Shadow Hawk 2H is the perfect example of a 'jack-of-all-trades.' It supports weaponry for all ranges, has respectable speed and jump capability, and mounts decent armor. This comes at the cost of excelling at nothing in particular. Quirk: Battle Fists Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.03

name: Shadow Hawk SHD-2Hb
details: The Shadow Hawk 2Hb was designed for the Star League's Royal regiments, which changed the mission profile to favor close range engagements exclusively. The -2Hb has little at range but is deadly dangerous up close thanks to its heavy weapons load. Quirk: Battle Fists Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.05

name: Shadow Hawk SHD-2Hb-EC
details: An early clan Mech dating from the days of Operation Klondike, the Shadow Hawk SHD-2Hb-EC was an upgrade of the Royal SHD-2Hb that replaced the weapons with Early Clan variants. It would be discontinued and forgotten as modern clan spec weapons entered production. Quirk: Battle Fists Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.05

name: Shadow Hawk SHD-2HR
details: A refit of the 2H, dropping 2 heat sinks to mount CASE protection for the ammunition and a C3 slave unit. Quirk: Battle Fists Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.03

name: Shadow Hawk SHD-2Ht
details: A Clan Buster upgrade, the Shadow Hawk 2Ht was a Comstar refit built with scrapped SLDF plans and modified for use as an Elemental hunter. Built on the standard SHD-2H chassis, the original 275-rated Fusion Core is retained along with the pair of arm mounted Medium Lasers. Replacing the AC/5 is a Large Laser, while 5 Streak SRM-2’s and a ton of ammo replace the original missile launchers. DHS replaces the original SHS, freeing up weight for CASE and an extra pair of Jump Jets. Quirk: Battle Fists Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.05

name: Shadow Hawk SHD-2I
details: The Shadow Hawk 2I variant comes with a UAC/10 coupled with a nasty Inferno Launcher, but in doing so sacrifices its jump capabilities. Quirk: Battle Fists Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.05

name: Shadow Hawk SHD-2K
details: The Shadow Hawk 2K removes all the armaments of the original, aside from its LRM-5, and replaces them with a single PPC. Five additional Heat Sinks are also added to help with the excess heat. Quirk: Battle Fists Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.03

name: Shadow Hawk SHD-2Ki
details: The Shadow Hawk 2Ki was conceived during the First Succession War by the Draconis Combine in 2803. As the enraged Federated Suns pushed the Kuritan troops back, the Draconis Combine dramatically overhauled the chassis by replacing almost all of its original armaments, most notably swapping in an upgraded PPC in place of an Autocannon. Quirk: Battle Fists Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.05

name: Shadow Hawk SHD-2P
details: Introduced in 2846, this variant of the Shadow Hawk replaces its AC/5 with a medium rifle, supplied by two tons of ammunition. Further changes include an additional ton of ammunition for the LRM-5 launcher, the removal of two single heat sinks and the installation of a supercharger. Quirk: Battle Fists Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.03

name: Shadow Hawk SHD-3H
details: A rare ''upgrade'' to the classic Shadow Hawk, the SHD-3H arose out of the political manoeuvring that surrounded the development of the Royal Shadow Hawk. Created as cover for the 2Hb program, the SHD-3H is a stock Shadow Hawk refitted for anti-insurgent work. A pair of Machine Guns and a ton of ammo replace the original SRM-2. The design can still be seen well into the 31st century with units lacking supplies often being forced to convert damaged 2H models to the 3H standard. Quirk: Battle Fists Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.03

name: Shadow Hawk SHD-3H2
details: An offshoot of the SHD-3H design, the Shadow Hawk SHD-3H2 is a full redesign of the 3H model. Intended for Terran Hegemony militia units, the 3H2 is optimised for anti-vehicle and anti-insurgent warfare. Somewhat slower then a standard Shadow Hawk due to the replacement of the 275 rated engine with a 220 rated one, the 3H2 uses the extra weight to pack in a pair of Small Lasers, 3 SRM-4 launchers and a Vehicular Grenade Launcher. Leftover Ferro-Fibrous armour from the Royal SHD-2Hb production line is used to improve armour protection. Quirk: Battle Fists Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.03

name: Shadow Hawk SHD-5M
details: The 5M Shadow Hawk is the first complete overhaul and upgrade of the design, unveiled in 3048 by Earthwerks for the Free Worlds League. The chassis has been upgraded to an Earthwerks SHD II Endo Steel frame, an additional ton of armor was added, two additional jump jets were fitted for a total jumping distance of 150 meters, the engine replaced with an extralight version of the Hermes 275, and the weapons load has undergone an almost complete renovation. The original autocannon has been updated to an Imperator Ultra Autocannon/5, the LRM launcher to a Doombud LRM-20, and the head-mounted SRM launcher to a Hovertec Streak SRM-2. The amount of ammunition carried and the left-arm medium laser are maintained, and while the number of heat sinks was reduced to ten these were upgrade to double-strength models. Quirk: Battle Fists Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.05

name: Shadow Hawk SHD-5S
details: This heavy scout variant carries a large laser in the right arm, a pair of medium lasers in each side torso, and a medium pulse laser with a coaxially mounted TAG system in the left arm. The left and right torso carry a Guardian ECM suite and a Beagle active probe, respectively, and a half ton of cargo space is provided in the head, probably for supplies on long reconnaissance missions. The most interesting change, however, is the use of a more powerful 330-rated XL engine that gives a top speed of 97.2 km/h which, when combined with five jump jets allowing 150 meter leaps, allows the 'Mech to get out of tight spots. Quirk: Battle Fists Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.05

name: Shadow Hawk SHD-5S2
details: The 5S2 has the same layout as the 5S, expect a slightly adjusted armor profile. Quirk: Battle Fists Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.05

name: Shadow Hawk SHD-5SF
details: The 5SF is a variant of the 5M used by the Special Forces. It replaces all standard weapons with one Large Laser, one medium pulse laser and four medium lasers. In addition, it carries a Beagle Active Probe and an ECM Suite. Quirk: Battle Fists Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.05

name: Shadow Hawk C
details: A Clan-tech retrofit of the classic Shadow Hawk and intended for second-line and solahma troops, the Shadow Hawk C replaces all Inner Sphere–tech weaponry with Clan equivalents. The C mounts an LB 5-X AC, an LRM-5 equipped with Swarm LRM munitions, a Streak SRM-2, and an ER medium laser. Two additional jump jets were added, extending the jump radius to 150 meters, as well as one additional single heat sink. Quirk: Battle Fists Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.03

name: Sheepdog SHE-1PD
details: The Sheepdog is more advanced than its first deceiving appearance, using Ferro-Fibrous armor, Endo Steel structure and an 100 XL engine - all to save weight. One medium laser and one small laser are accompanied by a strong sensor suite, a C3 slave and a MASC system for even faster movement. Quirk: Improved Sensors Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.99

name: Shogun SHG-2E
details:
Downgraded by the Dragoons to Succession Wars era technology the 2E simply carries a PPC in place of the ER PPC. Otherwise, the 2E is completely identical to the 2F model. Ironically, because the 2E uses an older PPC model, the PPC produces less heat at the cost of a shorter range than the 2F model, making the 'Mech's waste heat easier to manage. Quirk: Barrel Fist Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.15

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Lower, Right Lower

name: Shogun SHG-2F
details:
Though built for close combat, the weapons payload on the Shogun is built for long range combat. The 'Mech carries as its primary weapon a ER PPC and two LRM-15 launchers which allow the 'Mech to engage an enemy very effectively at long ranges. The 'Mech does also carry two SRM-6 launchers for close combat, allowing the 'Mech to find any weak spots in an enemy's armor when they do get to close ranges with the Shogun. Quirk: Barrel Fist Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.15

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Lower, Right Lower

name: Shogun SHG-2H
details:
The original 2777 Shogun model is similar to the 3050's era SHG-2F, adding Artemis IV fire control systems to the LRM racks. The SRM-6 racks are replaced with four Streak SRM-2 launchers, which share a single ton of ammunition. A head-mounted Medium Pulse Laser and a medium laser in the center torso rounds out the weapons. Armorscale ferro-fibrous armor and CASE protect the 'Mech. Quirk: Barrel Fist Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.15

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Lower, Right Lower

name: Shogun SHG-2TT
details:
A pirate refit of the Shogun, mounting three LRM-5 and three SRM-2 launchers in each arm, with a single standard PPC in the right torso. Quirk: Barrel Fist Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.13

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Lower, Right Lower

name: Shogun SHG-4F
details: An unofficial refresh of the SHG-2F, the 4F places the SRM launchers with Streak SRM-4s and adds an Artemis IV FCS for each LRM launcher. The design is obviously inspired the Shogun C the Wolf's Dragoons introduced to the Inner Sphere, but due to having no access to Clan-level technology the 4F is slightly worse in most regards. Quirk: Barrel Fist Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.15

name: Shogun SHG-4W
details:
The 4W is a custom variant of the Shogun brought by the Wolf's Dragoons to the Inner Sphere prior to the Clan Invasion. The fact it uses far more advanced technology than was available to the Great Houses meant its more efficient weapons loadout of two LRM-15 and four Streak SRM-6, combined with an ER PPC, really stood out. Quirk: Barrel Fist Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.21

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Lower, Right Lower

name: Shogun C
details:
A complete redesign of the Shogun using Clan technology that is used exclusively by Wolf's Dragoons, the Shogun C is armed with two LRM-20 missile racks with an Artemis IV fire control system for greater missile accuracy. The 'Mech also carries an ER PPC and four Streak SRM-6 launchers, giving it a devastating close range damage capability. Quirk: Barrel Fist Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.21

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Lower, Right Lower

name: Shootist ST-8A
details:
The Shootist first saw service in 2621 as a heavily armored, electronic warfare-capable command 'Mech for SLDF Royal BattleMech Regiments. However, the Shootist's upgraded electronic suites proved no match for the cutting edge of electronic warfare of its own time. When the BattleMaster eclipsed the Shootist in its intended role as a command vehicle merely ten years after its introduction, the SLDF changed the Shootist's mission parameters. The Shootist's balanced mix of weapons and speed, and its heavy armor allowed it a new role: juggernaut for close-combat heavy lances, and later, a bodyguard unit for command lances. This role never proved favorable to the longevity of the Shootist; since the Succession Wars, this BattleMech is rarely seen outside of the ComGuards, Word of Blake Militia, and ancient Clan Brian Caches. Quirk: Command Mech Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.1

Arm Actuator Limit: Left Upper

name: Shootist ST-8A2
details:
A variant of the standard Shootist ST-8A, the ST-8A2 is a refit designed to enhance the Mech's utility as a bodyguard for Command lances. A class D refit, the 8A2 replaces the standard Medium Pulse Lasers with standard Medium Lasers. The free tonnage this creates is used to install a Beagle Active Probe and upgrade the Small Laser to a Pulse model. Quirk: Command Mech Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.12

Arm Actuator Limit: Left Upper

name: Shrike SHR-1K
details: The Shrike relies on its speed to flank any foes, as it lacks the firepower to easily punch through the thicker frontal armor of most foes. Its equipped with four ER Medium Lasers and four Machine guns, and a single center torso mounted flamer. An ECM and active probe ensures the 'Mech can keep its targets locked. Quirk: Rugged Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.1

name: Shugenja SJA-7D
details:
Intended to keep its enemies at medium to long ranges, the Shugenja is armed with an ER PPC that is capable of striking an enemy at a distance, allowing the Shugenja to snipe at its victims. For just outside medium range to short range, the 'Mech carries a MRM-30 launcher and two Large Lasers. Quirk: Cowl Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.11

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Lower, Right Lower

name: Sidewinder Prime
details:
Apparently based on the Timber Wolf, the Sidewinder OmniMech was developed by Clan Cloud Cobra in preparation for the Clan Invasion of the Inner Sphere. When it turned out that the Cloud Cobras would likely not be among the invader clans they became increasingly desperate and eventually fielded a Sidewinder against Clan Jade Falcon in a trial on Babylon that they lost. The Jade Falcons salvaged the heavily damaged 'Mech and all available information is based on their investigation of the design. Quirk: Improved Lifesupport Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.12

Arm Actuator Limits: Omni

name: Siren 1
details: The Siren ProtoMech was originally designed by Clan Smoke Jaguar to serve as a reconnaissance unit. Its high speed allowed it to rush forward, find enemy forces, call in a missile strike, and evacuate without the enemy being able to see them. As the Siren was intended to be a scout and observer, it only carries a Light Machine Gun in either arm. Quirk: Nimble Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.96

name: Siren 2
details: The Siren ProtoMech was originally designed by Clan Smoke Jaguar to serve as a reconnaissance unit. Its high speed allowed it to rush forward, find enemy forces, call in a missile strike, and evacuate without the enemy being able to see them. Introduced during the 3060s, this variant of the Siren was upgraded with regular Machine Guns. Quirk: Nimble Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.96

name: Sirocco SRC-3C
details: Introduced in 3060, the 95-ton Sirocco was conceived as a replacement for the older Goliath QuadMech. Built by Corean Enterprises, the Sirocco is powered by a 285-rated Fusion Core giving it a top speed of 50 km/h. The Sirocco SRC-3C is armed with a pair of UAC/10s and a quad of ER Medium Lasers. A Medium Pulse Laser, two Anti-Personnel Pods and a Guardian ECM round out the arsenal. Quirk: Multi Trac Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.17

name: Sirocco SRC-5C
details: Introduced in 3060, the 95-ton Sirocco was conceived as a replacement for the older Goliath QuadMech. Built by Corean Enterprises, the Sirocco is powered by a 285-rated Fusion Core giving it a top speed of 50 km/h. The Sirocco SRC-5C is armed with a pair of Light Gauss Rifles and a quad of ER Medium Lasers. A Medium Pulse Laser, two Anti-Personnel Pods and a Guardian ECM round out the arsenal. Quirk: Multi Trac Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.17

name: Sling SL-1G
details:
Meant mostly as a high-speed fire support unit, the minimally-armored Sling was meant to remain out of the way of enemy fire, saturating the target area with its fifteen long-range missile tubes. Quirk: Accurate Weapon - Missiles Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.96

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Lower, Right Lower

name: Sling SL-1H
details:
Meant as a more traditional skirmish unit, the SL-1H replaced all three missile launchers with a pair of standard medium lasers and a single medium pulse laser. Quirk: Accurate Weapon - Energy Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.96

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Lower, Right Lower

name: Sloth (Standard)
details: The Inner Sphere adapted to battle armor quickly after being introduced to the concept by the Clan Elemental suit, so much so that the IS started innovating and testing the limits of what was possible almost immediately. In the 3050s the Lyran Commonwealth led the charge with this, the Sloth, the first quadruped battle armor. The Lyrans armed each suit with two Small Lasers and a BA-scale Pop-Up Mine, a weapon designed to penetrate armor and deal direct internal damage. The Sloth proved dangerous but unwieldy to control, making it unpopular with pilots. Quirk: Standard Parts Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.892 Can only be transported by internal bays, can not melee, can not swarm.

name: Slowpoke SLP-2U
details: The Slowpoke is armed with a single medium laser in the center torso. With a movement profile matching the infamous UrbanMech, its two and a half tons of armor is woefully inadequate even though it provides near maximum protection for a 'Mech of this small size. The jump jets can vault the Slowpoke 65 meters. Quirk: Rugged Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.99

name: Snake SNK-1V
details:
The Snake is a 'Mech that was built under the aegis of an Elemental hunter. With the power of hindsight though the Snake is clearly designed to hunt Inner Sphere Battle Armor suits. The 'Mech is built using a Vox 225 XL Engine to move at a top speed of 86.4 km/h. The Snake also has a jumping capability of one hundred and fifty meters making it capable of outmaneuvering any battle armor suit and also keeping it on par with most medium 'Mechs. The Snake is also armored with seven tons of armor and uses double heat sinks to cool the 'Mech's excess heat. Quirk: Improved Targeting - Short Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.03

Arm Actuator Limit: Right Lower

name: Snow Fox 1
details: Armed with only a head-mounted Series ER Medium Laser and a pair of ER Small Lasers, the Snow Fox excels at making high-speed passes. Though the 'Mech uses standard heat sinks, it takes an extremely bad pilot to cause the Snow Fox any overheating problems. Finally, it is protected as well as it can be by four tons of Ferro-Fibrous armor. Quirk: Narrow/Low Profile Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.01

name: Snow Fox 2
details: The first known variant of the Snow Fox introduced 3015 during the Succession Wars era or Golden Century. This variant replaces the lasers with an LRM-10, creating a very mobile support 'Mech. It is also incapable of building any noticeable amount of heat before it starts taking damage. Quirk: Narrow/Low Profile Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.01

name: Sorcerer SRC-1A
details: StarCorps Industries’s Project: SORCERER was shrouded in such secrecy that the first Sorcerer Battlemechs just seemed to appear in Star League Defense Force ranks where they were met with varying degrees of suspicion. The 95-ton Sorcerer 1A is built around a PlasmaStar 380XL engine to propel it to a respectable 64.8 km/h which enables the Sorcerer to bring its arsenal and Guardian ECM Suite to the enemy. The design carries a pair of Ceres Arms Smasher PPCs, a pair of Donal Snub-Nose PPCs, a pair of Magna MkII Medium Lasers, and a Magna MkI Small Laser. A staggering twenty Double Heat Sinks is barely enough to keep the weapons’ heat generation in check. Quirk: Battle Fists Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.17

name: Sorcerer SRC-1B
details: Shortly after the Sorcerer 1A began walking off of the StarCorps Industries production lines on Fletcher, the Sorcerer 1B began production in the satellite facility on Crofton. The 1B variant trades in the array of PPCs and Lasers for a Blankenburg Technologies ER PPC, a pair of Artemis IV-enhanced Holly LRM15s, and a trio of Defiance P5M Medium Pulse Lasers. The reduced Heat generation of this payload allowed designers to remove the five external Double Heat Sinks and freed up room for CASE in the right torso. Quirk: Battle Fists Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.17

name: Sorcerer SRC-1C
details: Despite being designed for Urban and close-quarters warfare, the Sorcerer 1C variant drops the pair Snub-Nosed PPCs of the original Sorcerer 1A in favor of the easier-to-obtain Blankenburg Large Pulse Lasers. Less surprisingly, the 1A’s PPC and laser complement is replaced by a quartet of Magna 400P Medium Pulse Lasers and a pair of Holly Streak SRM2s. The Sorcerer 1C dedicates eight tons to mount four Pitban LFT-50 jump jets to propel it 120 meters in short bursts and utilizes only sixteen Double Heat Sinks. Quirk: Battle Fists Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.17

name: Sorcerer SRC-1CC
details: Of the relatively few Sorcerers built before the Amaris Coup, the Sorcerer 1CC variant was considered an exceptionally rare design. Originally planned as a replacement for the 90 ton Cyclops, it quickly became apparent that the design teams at StarCorps Industries were not going to be able to best its incredible computer systems. Rather than spending several more decades of development, the design team decided that modifying the Sorcerer 1A would be a suitable method to cut corners. The 1CC drops the Snub-Nose PPCs, lasers and five Double Heat Sinks in order to mount an additional Ceres Arms Smasher PPC, a quintet of Magna 400P Medium Pulse Lasers, and the advanced Command Console. Quirk: Battle Fists Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.19

name: Sorcerer SRC-1X
details: StarCorps Industries’s Project: SORCERER is considered one of the best examples of effective counter-industrial espionage techniques; despite being in development for nearly two decades, the various intelligence agencies of the Great Houses never managed to collect any meaningful data on the program. The project’s primary goal was to create an assault BattleMech capable of slipping behind and operations behind enemy lines for an indefinite period of time and if at all possible, do this task undetected. Produced in exceptionally small quantities up until Amaris forces overran their facilities on Fletcher, the 95-ton Sorcerer 1X sports a combination of a Null Signature System and a Chameleon Light Polarization Shield. The 1X carries a pair of Ceres Arms Smasher PPCs, a pair of Donal Snub-Nose PPCs, and pair of Magna 400P Medium Pulse Lasers which in combination with the stealth systems onboard can easily overpower the Mech’s nineteen Double Heat Sinks. Few remember the 1X variant as the more widely-produced and fielded 1A variant stepped off of the manufacturing lines on the same day. Quirk: Battle Fists Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.19

name: Sorcerer SRC-2D
details: Like many designs lost during the Succession Wars, the Sorcerer design saw new life in the decades after the discovery of the Helm Memory Core. The Draconis Combine was the first to create a new variant of the aged SLDF design utilizing technologies at their disposal in 3058. The Sorcerer 2D retains the 380XL Engine, Guardian ECM Suite, one of the original PPCs, and thirteen of the original Double Heat Sinks and adds a pair of Shigunga MRM40s fed by four tons of ammo. A Small Laser is also added to the right arm for anti-personnel work. Quirk: Battle Fists Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.15

name: Spartan C
details: The Spartan C is the result of Clan-tech improvements by Clan Fire Mandrill to the original design. The C variant saw usage by a handful of the Clans, although only Clan Fire Mandrill continued to field the 'Mech through the invasion of the Inner Sphere. Quirk: Improved Sensors Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.18

name: Spartan SPT-N1
details: The earliest model of the Spartan assault 'Mech. The N1 suffered from inadequate cooling for its advanced weapons systems, which led to the design being revised into the more heat-efficient N2 in 2765. Despite this, a handful of N1 models still made their way into the hands of various buyers across the Sphere. Quirk: Improved Sensors Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.14

name: Spartan SPT-N2
details: Designed in 2765 as a response to rising hostility in the Periphery, the Spartan is a fast-moving assault 'Mech. During the Amaris Coup, the Martinson production line was destroyed, resulting in the Spartan's almost complete extinction; less than two dozen are known to still be in service. Quirk: Improved Sensors Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.14

name: Spartan SPT-NF
details: The NF variant of the Spartan is an upgrade of the standard N2 variant. The NF was fielded almost exclusively by the Star League Defense Force's Royal Divisions. Following the destruction of the Martinson production lines during the Amaris Coup, and the subsequent exodus of the SLDF, the design is considered extinct. Quirk: Improved Sensors Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.16

name: Spector SPR-4F
details:
The Spector was originally designed by Norse-Storm BattleMechs to be a lighter version of the Exterminator BattleMech, made to hunt down light command 'Mechs. The first Spector rolled off the assembly line on 6 June, 2639, and following extensive testing the SLDF ordered 600. The Star League's enthusiasm for the Spector is due to the BattleMechs stealth capabilities, a Chameleon Light Polarization Shield Quirk: Rugged Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.02

Arm Actuator Limit: Right Lower

name: Spector SPR-5F
details:
Reintroduced in 3053, the Spector mounts a Magna 245 XL engine in combination with an XL Engine and an Endo Steel chassis. It carries seven and a half tons of armor along with seven jump jets. The Spector carries a Nightwind Large Laser as its primary weapon, backed up by a pair of Defiance B3M Medium Lasers and a single Defiance B4S Small Laser for close combat. Defensively the Spector carries a Norse Guardian ECM Suite that allows it to defend itself against advanced enemy targeting and range finding equipment. Quirk: Rugged Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.05

Arm Actuator Limit: Right Lower

name: Spider IIC
details: The Spider IIC is armed with two ER Small Lasers and two Medium Pulse Lasers, with all of them linked through an advanced targeting computer. Ten double heat sinks are just barely enough to keep the 'Mech fully cooled in most situations. Quirk: Nimble Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.03

name: Spider SDR-5D
details: The 5D Spider is geared towards anti-infantry work, removing one of the medium lasers and replacing it with a Flamer in the right arm. However, the combination of its speed with the Flamer can deliver an unpleasant surprise. Quirk: Nimble Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.97

name: Spider SDR-5K
details: An anti-infantry variant, the 5K mounts Machine Guns in each arm along with a single Medium Laser in its center torso. In order to make room for the added weapons, a pair of JumpJets are removed, hampering some of the Spider's vaunted mobility. Quirk: Nimble Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.97

name: Spider SDR-5V
details: The Spider 5V is hands down the most maneuverable 'Mech you can field, but it's made of paper. It's an excellent scout, though, and can even jump into the rear arc of most enemies for surprise back shots. Quirk: Nimble Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.97

name: Spider SDR-5VR
details: A simple refit of the Spider SDR-5V, this variant drops two jump jets to fit a C3 slave computer. Quirk: Nimble Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.97

name: Spider SDR-5WDR
details: A major upgrade of the 5V, this custom variant used by the mercenary outfit Wolf's Dragoons make the Spider be a far more capable 'Mech by upgrading almost all the equipment with Clan tech. However, even with more tons being added due to the use of Ferro-Fibrous armor, the main flaw of it still remains in the lack of proper protection. Quirk: Nimble Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.05

name: Spider SDR-7M
details: The 7M was Nimakachi's upgrade of the venerable Spider with recovered Star League technology. Released in 3051 it uses a Crucis-II Delux Endo Steel chassis and three tons of Kallon FWL Special Ferro-Fibrous armor, freeing up weight to replace the two medium lasers with two Tronel XII medium pulse lasers. Many of the components were also replaced with proprietary technology, including Rawlings 75 jump jets, an Omicron 4002 Networking Channel, and a TRSS Eagle Eye targeting system. One thing they could not do however was include an ejection system for the pilot. Quirk: Nimble Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.99

name: Spider SDR-8M
details: The 8M is a simple upgrade of the 7M developed by the FWLM in 3060, replacing the single heat sinks with double strength versions. Otherwise, both variants are completely identical. Quirk: Nimble Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.99

name: Spider SDR-C
details: This Draconis Combine variant, introduced in 3054 and based on the 7M, swaps out one of the pulse lasers for a standard medium and a C3 Slave Unit. Quirk: Nimble Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.99

name: Spider SDR-I1
details: The Spider I1 is a cheap refit from the Frontier Worlds that comes with a Plasma Cutter and Fluid Gun, along with marginally improved armor. Quirk: Nimble Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.97

name: Spirit Walker A
details: The Alpha loadout of the Spirit Walker is mainly focused on powerful, direct engagements head on. A combination of lasers, machine guns and even a Gauss Rifle ensures the 'Mech can deliver damage at practically any distance of engagements. However, it's relative slow speed makes it vulnerable to being flanked or outmaneuvered by more agile units. Quirk: Rugged Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.1

name: Spirit Walker Prime
details: The Primary configuration requires a very skilled MechWarrior to operate properly, using advanced volley and engage tactics. During the volley phase the 'Mech should engage with some of its ER Large Lasers, but keeping heat under control. As the engagement distance shrinks, the use of the Large Lasers should be switched to the Medium Pulse Lasers instead. If at any point all lasers will be fire together, the 'Mech will most likely instantly go into overheat shutdown. Quirk: Rugged Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.1

name: Stag II ST-24G
details:
The so-called Stag II incorporated a prototype version of the ER PPC that was roughly comparable to the Clan version of the weapon, though it was slightly less destructive. This upgrade of the large laser necessitated removal of the MASC, though the top speed was upgraded to 119 km/h. Additionally, Ferro-Fibrous weave was incorporated into the armor, though at an overall decrease in protection. The SRMs were removed in favor of an additional Medium Laser, two Medium Pulse Lasers, and two Small Lasers. This gave the 'Mech greater battlefield longevity, though the potential for excessive heat buildup was much greater. Quirk: Improved Communications Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.03

Arm Actuator Limit: Right Lower

name: Stag ST-14G
details:
The Stag was built on an Endo Steel frame and powered by an XL Engine. Ten tons of armor provided the 'Mech with the maximum possible protection. The long-range threat from the cavalry 'Mech comes from one ER Large Laser. At close range it is supplemented by paired Medium Lasers and SRM-4s. Two, CASE-protected tons of ammunition gives MechWarriors the flexibility to use different types of munitions, making the Stag a threat to a variety of units. Twelve double heat sinks handles all of the heat generated by the weapons. Quirk: Improved Communications Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.03

Arm Actuator Limit: Right Lower

name: Stalker STK-3F
details:
The Stalker 3F mounts a ridiculous amount of weaponry, even for an assault 'Mech. It is also notable for its incredibly poor heat management, which is the cost it pays for such amazing damage output. Powerful, but to be used wisely. Quirk: Combat Computer Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.13

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Upper, Right Upper

name: Stalker STK-3Fb
details:
Created for the Star League's Royal regiments, the Stalker-3Fb is much like its lesser kin: a walking death machine. It carries a similar payload but makes use of lostech double heat sinks to cool down much more effectively, letting it fire continuously much longer than a normal Stalker-3F. Quirk: Combat Computer Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.15

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Upper, Right Upper

name: Stalker STK-3Fk
details:
A unit used by the 4th Sword of Light, this variant of the Stalker replaces the heat sinks with Double Heat Sinks, adds Artemis IV FCS to the LRM-10 launchers, and replaces the SRM-6 packs with four Streak SRM-2 systems. Quirk: Combat Computer Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.15

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Upper, Right Upper

name: Stalker STK-3FR
details:
A battlefield refit of the -3F, adding some more protection for the MechWarriors piloting the 'Mech in form of CASE protection for the ammunition and an armored cowl for the cockpit. Quirk: Combat Computer Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.13

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Upper, Right Upper

name: Stalker STK-3H
details:
The Stalker 3H was intended as a siege 'Mech. Replacing the twin LRM-10s and Large Lasers for paired LRM-20s, the STK-3H is a powerful fire support 'Mech. Quirk: Combat Computer Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.13

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Upper, Right Upper

name: Stalker STK-3W
details:
A total refit of the -3F, replacing much of the equipment and weapons with aquired clan tech. Mainly seen amongst the more prominent Mercenary outfits, such as the Wolf's Dragoons or Kell Hounds. Quirk: Combat Computer Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.15

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Upper, Right Upper

name: Stalker STK-4F
details:
The -4F is a refresh of the -3F, updating its weaponry and using an Endo Steel chassis. The build is focused around two MRM-30 launchers and two ER Large Lasers, with four Medium Pulse Lasers providing extra firepower as needed. However, the design struggles majorly with heat even with 5 external double heat sinks, reducing its combat effectiveness. Quirk: Combat Computer Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.15

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Upper, Right Upper

name: Stalker STK-4H
details:
A field refit of the -3H, upgrading the SRM6 launchers to Streak models and the Medium lasers to Pulse variants. Taking the design back to the root of the -3F model, two ER Large Lasers are added by changing to an Endo Steel chassis and downgrading the LRM launchers to 10 tubes each. Quirk: Combat Computer Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.15

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Upper, Right Upper

name: Stalker STK-4N
details:
By removing one of the LRM launchers and adding more Heat Sinks, the Stalker 4N can dish out more damage per round without as much fear of baking the pilot alive. Quirk: Combat Computer Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.13

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Upper, Right Upper

name: Stalker STK-4P
details:
Due to ongoing structural weakness issues with the aging Stalker chassis, it was necessary to reduce the load by 10 tons by removing a LRM launcher effectively reclassifying this variant as a Heavy 'Mech. Quirk: Combat Computer Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.09

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Upper, Right Upper

name: Stalker STK-5M
details:
An upgrade originating from the Free Worlds League, the 5M variant of the Stalker was introduced in 3050 using moderate amounts of Star League technology. Most of the weaponry was retained but both large lasers were removed for a single Diverse Optics Sunbeam ER Large Laser placed in the 'Mech's centerline and a Narc Missile Beacon in the left torso accompanied by two tons of reloads, allowing the Stalker to tag enemy units with homing beacon and direct friendly missile fire onto them. The seventeen double heat sinks of the 5M afford it far greater heat efficiency than the twenty single heat sinks of previous models, although it still could not handle firing all of its weaponry simultaneously, and an additional ton of armor was added for survivability. Other changes included the use of proprietary components such as an Irian E.A.R. communications system, Riese-456 armor and a Irian Chassis Class 30. Unfortunately the designers of the new 5M dismissed the inclusion of CASE, a factor which led directly to the deaths of several Stalkers during the Clan Invasion due to ammunition cook-offs caused by overheating and weapon penetrations. Quirk: Combat Computer Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.15

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Upper, Right Upper

name: Stalker STK-5S
details:
Outfitted with the relatively recently rediscovered Star League technology of circa 3050, the FedCom 5S can be characterized primarily by its tendency to overheat. The designers behind this variant took the simple expedient of upgrading its engine and firepower without taking heat build-up into consideration. The 'Mech has had its engine replaced with an XL Engine and the large lasers have been removed and replaced with two Thunderbolt-12 Large Pulse Lasers. For protection against ammunition explosions, CASE has been added to both side torsos, and an Deprus Swarmshot Anti-Missile System has been added for protection against incoming missiles. Quirk: Combat Computer Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.15

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Upper, Right Upper

name: Stalking Spider 1
details: The big gun on the Stalking Spider is its ER PPC, which allows it deal a strong strike from long ranges. For close-up work, it has a pair of SRM-4 launchers and a pair of Medium Pulse Lasers. While the design can build a significant amount of heat if the MechWarrior constantly alpha strikes, an experienced pilot should be able to manage the Stalking Spider's heat easily. The design can stay at long range and snipe with its ER PPC, then quickly close to finish off an opponent with its pulse lasers and missiles. Quirk: Stable Weapons Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.1

name: Stalking Spider 2
details: This variant of the Stalking Spider, introduced 3060, removes the PPC and missiles, but retains the pulse lasers. It adds a Heavy Large Laser and a Targeting Computer to direct the 'Mech's laser fire. This hunter-killer is aided by the inclusion of an Active Probe and TAG. An additional double heat sink keeps heat levels manageable. Quirk: Stable Weapons Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.1

name: Starslayer STY-2C
details:
A Star League era mech, the Starslayer was intended to replace the Crab as the SLDF’s standard medium chassis, though politics kept it from seeing full production until 2781. A 50 ton medium mech, the Starslayer is powered by a 250-rated fusion core and has 5 JJ’s for maximum mobility. The STY-2C carries 2 Large Lasers, with a pair of Medium Lasers and a Small laser for closer ranged combat. An SRM-4 with a ton of ammo rounds out the design. Quirk: Rugged Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.04

Arm Actuator Limit: Right Upper

name: Starslayer STY-2C-EC
details:
A Star League era mech, the Starslayer was intended to replace the Crab as the SLDF’s standard medium chassis, though politics kept it from seeing full production until 2781. A 50 ton medium mech, the Starslayer is powered by a 250-rated fusion core and has 5 JJ’s for maximum mobility. The STY-2C-EC was an early clan mech, incorporating new technology into the older 2C chassis. It carries Improved Large Lasers, supported by 2 Prototype ER Medium Lasers and a Prototype ER Small. A Prototype Streak SRM-4 rounds out the design. Quirk: Rugged Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.02

Arm Actuator Limit: Right Upper

name: Starslayer STY-3C
details:
A Star League era mech, the Starslayer was intended to replace the Crab as the SLDF’s standard medium chassis, though politics kept it from seeing full production until 2781. A 50 ton medium mech, the Starslayer is powered by a 250-rated fusion core and has 5 JJ’s for maximum mobility. The STY-3C carries 2 Large Lasers, with a pair of Medium Lasers and a Small laser for closer ranged combat. An SRM-4 with a ton of ammo rounds out the design. Quirk: Rugged Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.04

Arm Actuator Limit: Right Upper

name: Starslayer STY-3D
details:
A Star League era mech, the Starslayer was intended to replace the Crab as the SLDF’s standard medium chassis, though politics kept it from seeing full production until 2781. A 50 ton medium mech, the Starslayer is powered by a 250-rated fusion core and has 5 JJ’s for maximum mobility. The STY-3D carries a Large laser and a PPC, with a trio of Medium Lasers rounding out the design. Quirk: Rugged Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.04

Arm Actuator Limit: Right Upper

name: Stiletto STL-7D
details: The STL-7D Stiletto was one of very few ultralight BattleMechs designed for a specific combat role: to fight short-range delaying actions and to engage the Lyran Commonwealth's new COM-2D Commando reconnaissance 'Mech. During the 2460s and 2470s, quantities of Commandos began appearing in regiments along the Steiner/Kurita border, a situation that concerned Lord Kurita greatly. Deciding to assume the offensive, he ordered a new BattleMech design constructed, cheaper than its intended adversary and available in quantity. The result, the Stiletto, entered full-scale production in 2473. Quirk: Easy to Maintain Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.97

name: Stiletto STO-3A
details:
As all the other 3-series variants, the Stiletto STO-3A is focused on longer range indirect fire, as its three LRM-5 launchers makes evident. For short range defense a single Stream SRM-2 is mounted in the center torso. Quirk: Multi Trac Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.05

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Upper, Right Upper

name: Stiletto STO-3J
details:
The Stiletto 3J adds ferro-fibrous armor and an endo steel chassis to enable the addition of 8 jump jets. Another sacrifice that had to be made was the removal of the C.A.S.E. protection for the two tons of missile ammunition kept in the right torso. Quirk: Multi Trac Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.05

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Upper, Right Upper

name: Stiletto STO-3W
details:
The 3W trades one LRM-5 launcher and the Stream SRM launcher for a Large Pulse Laser, making the 'Mech capable to handles prolonged engagements without the MechWarrior having to worry about being complexly defenseless once all the ammunition is used up. Quirk: Multi Trac Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.05

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Upper, Right Upper

name: Stiletto STO-4A
details:
The Stiletto was engineered in a similar vein as the Black Hawk-KU or the Rakshasa, using examples of Fire Falcon OmniMechs salvaged from the battlefield immediately following the Battle of Coventry. The Stiletto has an identical speed profile as the Fire Falcon with a VOX 280 Light Engine giving it a top speed of 129.6 km/h. Quirk: Multi Trac Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.05

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Upper, Right Upper

name: Stinger LAM STG-A1
details: The original Stinger LAM used by the Star League Defense Force Royal Divisions, this version carried a Medium Pulse Laser and replaced the Machine Guns with Small Pulse Lasers. Double heat sinks kept the temperature manageable. It was also more heavily armored than its forerunner, carrying five tons of protection. Quirk: Land Air Mech Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.01

name: Stinger LAM STG-A5
details: In 2680, the Star League requested designers to develop 'Mechs which could fly as well as function as standard 'Mechs. The first Land-Air 'Mech off the drawing board, the Shadow Hawk LAM, proved so fatally flawed, the concept was almost shelved. However, LexaTech Industries reworked the conversion equipment and unveiled the first viable LAM, the Stinger LAM in 2688, based on the old Stinger design. LexaTech's reworking of the concept proved so successful, the Land-Air 'Mech became highly sought after, especially for space combat operations. In fact, the Stinger LAM first saw combat destroying a nuclear weapons facility in the Oort Cloud orbiting Sol, Terra's star. The standard production model uses three Magna Medium Lasers mounted on the head and arms. Quirk: Land Air Mech Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.99

name: Stinger LAM STG-A10
details: In 2680, the Star League requested designers to develop 'Mechs which could fly as well as function as standard 'Mechs. The first Land-Air 'Mech off the drawing board, the Shadow Hawk LAM, proved so fatally flawed, the concept was almost shelved. However, LexaTech Industries reworked the conversion equipment and unveiled the first viable LAM, the Stinger LAM in 2688, based on the old Stinger design. LexaTech's reworking of the concept proved so successful, the Land-Air 'Mech became highly sought after, especially for space combat operations. In fact, the Stinger LAM first saw combat destroying a nuclear weapons facility in the Oort Cloud orbiting Sol, Terra's star. Found in the Draconis Combine, this variant uses two pairs of Martell Small Lasers on the arms instead of a single Medium Laser. Quirk: Land Air Mech Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.99

name: Stinger LAM STG-A10C
details: In 2680, the Star League requested designers to develop 'Mechs which could fly as well as function as standard 'Mechs. The first Land-Air 'Mech off the drawing board, the Shadow Hawk LAM, proved so fatally flawed, the concept was almost shelved. However, LexaTech Industries reworked the conversion equipment and unveiled the first viable LAM, the Stinger LAM in 2688, based on the old Stinger design. LexaTech's reworking of the concept proved so successful, the Land-Air 'Mech became highly sought after, especially for space combat operations. In fact, the Stinger LAM first saw combat destroying a nuclear weapons facility in the Oort Cloud orbiting Sol, Terra's star. Found in the Draconis Combine, this variant uses two pairs of Martell Small Lasers on the arms instead of a single Medium Laser. Quirk: Land Air Mech Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.99

name: Stinger STG-3G
details: The 3G Stinger was the only mainstream variant of the Stinger to achieve any sort of popularity prior to the Clan Invasion. First debuting in 2581, it traded the two machine guns for a second medium laser mounted on the left arm. While this variant increased the Stinger's lethality against other 'Mechs, it also made heat management a little more complicated for less experienced MechWarriors. Quirk: Ubiquitous Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.95

name: Stinger STG-3Gb
details: The SLDF improved upon the stock Stinger with the addition of many new technologies unavailable when the 'Mech was first designed. Designed as a fast, jump-capable reconnaissance platform, the Stinger has served capably in that role for well over half a millennium, a testament to the utility of the original design. Quirk: Ubiquitous Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.97

name: Stinger STG-3GD
details: The Stinger STG-3GD is a custom Clan-tech full conversion fielded by the mercenary command known as Grey Death Legion. One ER Medium Laser and two Heavy Machine Guns combined with its mobility fulfills the role of an anti-squad and infantry capable scout 'Mech. Quirk: Ubiquitous Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.97

name: Stinger STG-3R
details: Designed as a fast, jump-capable reconnaissance platform, the Stinger has served capably in that role for well over half a millennium, a testament to the utility of the original design Quirk: Ubiquitous Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.95

name: Stinger STG-3RR
details: A common field refit of the 3R, replacing the Machine Guns with an extra Medium Laser and a C3 slave unit. Quirk: Ubiquitous Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.95

name: Stinger STG-3T
details: Created in 3057, the Stinger 3T is a product of a joint project between Pinard Protectorates and Vandenburg Mechanized Industries to develop an upgraded Stinger for use by the TDF. Based on the STG-3R, the 3T swaps the Machine Guns for Small Lasers and the Medium Laser for a Pulse model. Ferro-Fibrous armor is used to increase protection. Quirk: Ubiquitous Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.97

name: Stinger STG-5M
details: This upgraded version of the Stinger produced by Earthwerks Incorporated on Keystone and Calloway VI took advantage of several technologies that were rediscovered, thanks in part to the Helm Memory Core. The chassis was upgraded to an Earthwerks STG II Endo Steel model, allowing it to carry an additional half-ton of armor. The 'Mech retained the Omicron medium laser but swapped the machine guns for a Lindblad Shotgun Anti-Missile System on its right arm and a Flame Tech Flamer on its left. One ton of AMS ammo was carried in the right torso, while the Datacom 26 and Dynatec 990 electronic systems remain unchanged. Quirk: Ubiquitous Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.97

name: Stinger C
details: The Stinger Cs emerging from the Wolf Empire's Keystone factory mirror those of the early Clans. Initially developed by the Hell's Horses as a training unit, other Clans found the Stinger to be a competent fighter, especially useful when Trials did not necessitate wasting larger, more valuable BattleMechs. An ER Medium Laser, two Machine Guns and a Small Pulse Laser makes for an surprising amount of damage potential from such a light 'Mech. Quirk: Ubiquitous Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.01

name: Stinger C 2
details: The C 2, created by the Blood Spirits, swaps the machine guns for another laser. The Wolves deploy this variant as a harasser, reserving the primary version for scouting and anti-piracy duties. Quirk: Ubiquitous Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.01

name: Stinger STG-M1 'First Modification'
details: The M1, nicknamed 'First Modification' by the techs on Chara III, is a field modification of the STG-3R that exchanges both machine guns and their ammunition for four small lasers, two mounted in each arm. Quirk: Ubiquitous Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.97

name: Stinger STG-M2 'Second Modification'
details: The M2, nicknamed 'Second Modification' by the techs on Chara III, is a field modification of the STG-3R that exchanges the jump jets for two medium lasers in the center torso and another ton of armor. Quirk: Ubiquitous Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.97

name: Stone Rhino 1
details:
The design featured Large Pulse Lasers in each arm, twin Gauss Rifles mounted behind flip-open circular firing ports on each side torso, and an almost superfluous Small Pulse Laser located above the cockpit. The Stone Rhino also sported an interesting feature; each arm contained a retractable, shock-absorbing cowl covering the weapon barrels. This allowed MechWarriors to use the arms as battering rams without damaging the weaponry. Quirk: Distracting Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.22

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Upper, Right Upper

name: Stone Rhino 2
details:
In order to plug holes in their touman, Clan Goliath Scorpion scientists revisited the Behemoth. Like Clan Smoke Jaguar before them, they upgraded and improved upon the design. This version used an Extra-light Engine to mount a pair of Thunderstroke Series 2b Gauss Rifles along the top of the 'Mech. Each arm carried a Series 4D-2 Heavy Large Laser, a Series 22a Heavy Medium Laser, and a General Systems Heavy Small Laser. It retained the shock-absorbing cowls of the original. Another pair of Heavy Mediums protected the rear of the 'Mech. A head-mounted Shield-3 Anti-Missile System defended against missiles, while an Anti-Personnel Pod in each leg discouraged unarmored infantry. This design had jump jets, nineteen tons of armor, and a meager sixteen double heat sinks. Quirk: Distracting Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.24

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Upper, Right Upper

name: Stone Rhino 4
details:
A variable range variant, the Stone Rhino 4 uses an XL Engine to provide weight savings for four LRM 10s to lay down impressive long range fire. Backing these up are a pair of Ultra AC-10s for mid-range engagements. From there, four ER Medium Lasers provide a solid short range punch. Lastly, four Machine Guns provide anti-infantry support. These combine to make a solid and well rounded configuration. Quirk: Distracting Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.22

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Upper, Right Upper

name: Stone Rhino 5
details:
A design based off of early specifications for Amaris's Folly, the Stone Rhino 5 uses a 400XL engine to reach speeds up up to 64.8 km/h. It is armed with four LB-5X Autocannons mounted in the torsos backed up by six ER Medium Lasers in the arms. Quirk: Distracting Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.22

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Upper, Right Upper

name: Stone Rhino 6
details:
A close combat design based on the Stone Rhino 5, the Stone Rhino 6 is armed with a simple yet effective loadout of 14 Medium Pulse Lasers. These are backed up by a single ER Small Laser. Quirk: Distracting Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.22

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Upper, Right Upper

name: Stone Rhino 7
details:
With the STR-7 variant being designed for space operations, its full weaponry is energy based as to work efficiently in a vacuum environment, and the leg actuators have been reinforced to handle higher loads. The variant mounts a Large Pulse Laser on each Arm, a ER Larger Laser in each torso location and a Small Pulse Laser in the Head. 14 external Double Heat Sinks allows the STR-7 to operate its weapons and three Jump Jets inside an atmosphere. Quirk: Distracting Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.22

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Lower, Right Lower

name: Stone Rhino 'Nocturnis'
details:
A Clan redesign of 'Amaris Folly'. Quirk: Distracting Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.22

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Lower, Right Lower

name: Stooping Hawk A
details:
A direct-fire support loadout, the A uses a pair of ER PPCs. It retains the jump jets of the primary configuration to aid in finding a spot to snipe from. The variant also mounts seven additional double heat sinks to keep the heat buildup controlled. Quirk: Rugged Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.06

Arm Actuator Limits: Omni

name: Stooping Hawk B
details:
The B configuration is a missile boat that is capable of delivering forty-five long-range missiles through its three LRM-15 launchers, each of which is aided by an Artemis IV FCS. Four tons of ammunition keep it well supplied, while a single ER Large Laser keeps it in the fight should ammunition run out. Quirk: Rugged Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.06

Arm Actuator Limits: Omni

name: Stooping Hawk C
details:
The Stooping Hawk C comes equipped with two ER Large Lasers and two ER Medium Lasers, all of which are guided by an advanced Targeting Computer. It also uses jump jets to vault up to 150 meters, like the A, and it makes use of seven additional double heat sinks, like the A. Quirk: Rugged Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.06

Arm Actuator Limits: Omni

name: Stooping Hawk D
details:
This D configuration uses heavy laser technology captured from Clan Star Adder. The medium-range weaponry allows the 'Mech to excel at Trials where it can use cover (and its jumping ability) to its advantage. Quirk: Rugged Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.06

A pair of LRM-20’s make up the bulk of the Mechs firepower, with a pair of SSRM-6’s and a UAC/20 for close range combat. Quirk: Rugged Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.22

details:

Built with the rugged GM 240 fusion engine, the Strider has a top speed of 97.2 km/h. Outfitted with CASE, built around the durable GM 240, and protected with seven and a half tons of armor, the Strider is a durable 'Mech for its weight class; capable of suffering considerable damage before being disabled or destroyed. name: Striker STC-2C
details:
The Striker STC-2C is built using rugged, off-the-shelf technologies that allow it to stand up to a great deal of punishment and enable easy repair. The 2C has a top speed of 64.8 km/h, provided by a 320-rated Fusion engine. For protection, it carries thirteen and a half tons of armor, solidly average for a 'Mech of the Striker's size. The Striker STC-2C dissipates the heat from its arsenal with fifteen standard heat sinks. It has an arsenal that is capable of engaging an enemy at a variety of ranges. At maximum range, the 2C brings its PPC and a AC/5 to bear. As the enemy closes, it can also make use of its Large Laser, though the unit's pilot will need to monitor their heat generation carefully. Finally, for close range defense, it has three Medium Lasers. Quirk: Easy to Maintain Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.12

A Draconis Combine developed Omni mech, the Sunder is based on reverse engineered Loki and Thor Omnimechs. A 360-rated XL Engine allows the omnimech to carry 15 DHS along with 16.5 tons of armor and 36 tons of weapons. The Sunder SD1-OR is armed with a Clan LB-10X and a pair of Clan Large Pulse Lasers. 4 Clan ER Medium Lasers and paired Clan Streak-6’s act as secondary weapons. Quirk: Extended Torso Twist Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.11

Arm Actuator Limits: Omni

name: Super Wasp WSP-2A-X
details: The WSP-2A-X Super Wasp is an evolution of the classic Wasp, a re-design that essentially produced a new BattleMech with even a different tonnage. Weighing as much as a Commando, the Super Wasp maintained the basic ground speed and jump capability of its inspiration, but also added an engine Supercharger which allowed it to sprint at speeds of up to 120 km/h. Quirk: Aerial Assault Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.96

name: Supernova 1
details:
The Supernova 1's only armaments are six Clan ER Large Lasers. While this is a fair amount of firepower for a 'Mech of its size, it has a severe overheating problem. After firing no more than three full, consecutive salvos, the Supernova will force an automatic shutdown, so MechWarriors must carefully manage their heat. Quirk: Improved Targeting - Long Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.2

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Lower, Right Lower

name: Supernova A
details:
Apparently based on the Supernova-2, the Supernova-A retains only a single ER Large Laser in each arm, mounting an Artemis IV FCS-equipped LRM-20 and Streak SRM-6 launcher in each torso. With a targeting computer linked to the large lasers, three tons of LRM missiles and four tons of Streak reloads give the A variant good endurance. Keeping the classic jump jets and boosting armor over primary variant, an Endo Steel frame and fitting only seventeen double heat sinks are used to free up the extra weight required for the missile launchers. Quirk: Improved Targeting - Long Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.22

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Lower, Right Lower

name: Supernova C
details:
Somewhat of an anomaly, unlike its brothers the Supernova-C mounts its primary weapons in its torsos and secondary weapons in its arms; twin Large Pulse Lasers in each side torso supported by a ER Medium and Medium Pulse Laser in each arm. Built on the framework of the Supernova-2, the C mounts twenty-two double heat sinks. Quirk: Improved Targeting - Long Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.2

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Lower, Right Lower

name: Swordsman SWD-1
details: The Swordsman was an early Federated Suns medium-class BattleMech which was originally built in 2463 as House Davion's third in-house BattleMech design. The design was tainted by heavy use in the Davion Civil War of 2525-2540. Eventually, production ended and the design was relegated to the dustbin of history. However, in the 3060s, the mech was put back into production by House Davion to supplement their forces in the FedCom Civil War. The SWD-2 is the stock production design, mounting heavy armor and firepower for the tonnage: 7.5 tons of armor and a grab-bag mix of guns including an AC/5, LRM-5, SRM-4, two Medium Lasers, and a Small Laser. Quirk: Integrated Searchlight Drop Cost Multiplier: 1

name: Swordsman SWD-2
details: The Swordsman was an early Federated Suns medium-class BattleMech which was originally built in 2463 as House Davion's third in-house BattleMech design. The design was tainted by heavy use in the Davion Civil War of 2525-2540. Eventually, production ended and the design was relegated to the dustbin of history. However, in the 3060s, the mech was put back into production by House Davion to supplement their forces in the FedCom Civil War. The SWD-2 is the stock production design, mounting heavy armor and firepower for the tonnage: 7.5 tons of armor and a grab-bag mix of guns including an AC/5, LRM-5, SRM-4, two Medium Lasers, and a Small Laser. Quirk: Integrated Searchlight Drop Cost Multiplier: 1

name: Sylph [STD]
details: The Sylph was created by Clan Cloud Cobra to augment their vast aerospace forces with a fully-airborne battle armor suit. Naming it after elemental spirits representing air, development of the suit was driven as much by the Cloud Cobra's faith as it was by Khan Din Steiner's orders. Despite their scientist caste's vast knowledge of aircraft, the Clan had a great deal of trouble getting the VTOL capabilities of the Sylph to function, with a number of test pilots dying during its secretive development. As it is, the Sylph only possesses limited flight capabilities, but even this remains an impressive accomplishment. Quirk: Nimble Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.9475 Can mount Omni units, can melee, can swarm.

name: Tai-sho TSH-7S
details:
The Tai-sho concentrates on keeping an enemy at long range and using targeting data from friendly units to enhance its long range capabilities. The primary weapons it carries are a pair of ER PPCs capable of keeping an adversary at arms reach. These are backed up by an Ultra Autocannon/10 which can fire at twice the rate of a standard autocannon. Quirk: Improved Communications Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.15

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Lower, Right Lower

name: Talon TLN-3L
details: The 3L has a lackluster range of weapons compared to the other variants of the Talon; three Medium Lasers and one Small Laser. The 'Mech is instead focused more on the scouting role, with a Beagle Active Probe and an Angel ECM suite. Quirk: Rugged Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.98

name: Talon TLN-5V
details:
A Star League era mech, the Talon debuted in 2670 as a light fire support mech. Rendered extinct by the destruction of the Succession Wars, it re-entered production in 3056, though the Clans retain a number of SLDF models from the Exodus. Built around a 280 XL Engine, the Talon TLN-5V is armed with a PPC and a pair of Medium Lasers. Quirk: Rugged Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.05

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Upper, Right Upper

name: Talon TLN-5VNO
details:
The 5VNO is a downgraded Succession Wars era version using a standard 210 engine, reducing its ground speed down to a maximum of 90 km/h with seven and a half tons of standard armor. It has a single PPC in the right arm for ranged combat, backed up pair of medium lasers in the left arm. This design has no lower arm actuators allowing it to flip its weapons into the rear arc. A few units have been reported fielded by pirates. Quirk: Rugged Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.98

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Upper, Right Upper

name: Talon TLN-5W
details:
A Star League era mech, the Talon debuted in 2670 as a light fire support mech. Rendered extinct by the destruction of the Succession Wars, it re-entered production in 3056, though the Clans retain a number of SLDF models from the Exodus. Built around a 280 XL Engine, the Talon TLN-5W is armed with an ER PPC and a pair of Medium Lasers. Quirk: Rugged Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.05

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Upper, Right Upper

name: Talon TLN-5W-EC
details:
A Star League era mech, the Talon debuted in 2670 as a light fire support mech. Rendered extinct by the destruction of the Succession Wars, it re-entered production in 3056, though the Clans retain a number of SLDF models from the Exodus. Built around a 280 XL Engine, the Talon TLN-5W-EC was an early Clan upgrade from the dawn of the Golden Century. The Talon 5W-EC is armed with an Enhanced ER PPC and a pair of Medium Lasers. Quirk: Rugged Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.98

Arm Actuator Limits: Left Upper, Right Upper

name: Talos TLS-1B
details:
While an exceptionally early design, the Talos by Vandenberg MilTech was a financial success and a long-standing general mech for the Taurian Defense Forces from its production in the 2530's well into the Succession Wars. An Autocannon/10, two LRM-5s, and an SRM-6 give the Talos weapons effective at multiple range bands while its 8.5 tons of armor give it some longevity on the battlefield. Quirk: Easy to Pilot Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.02

Arm Actuator Limit: Right Lower

name: Talos TLS-1P
details:
A relic of an earlier age, it's a minor miracle this antique is still functional. Occasionally found through the frontier, surviving Taloses are a strange mix of new and old technology, bodged together by generations of different mectechs. Rarely seen and even more rarely fielded in battle, very few of these 500 year old designs still grace the modern battlefield, but those that do are treated with the respect and reverence, due to a centuries old design. The 1P is the "modern" adaptation of the older 1B design and has proliferated in recent years, leading some to speculate that a cache of Talos or Talos parts has been found. Armed with a variety of local tech and a knock-off ecm suite, the 1P is a versatile design outfitted as a mid range brawler. Quirk: Easy to Pilot Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.02

Arm Actuator Limit: Right Lower

name: Talos TLS-4A
details:
With the reintroduction of Helm Core LosTech, the Taurian Defense Force found themselves lagging behind their neighbours. Just as they did during the Age of War, the Taurians turned to the home grown Talos. With a reputation as an easy to maintain and easy to manufacture mech, the design was just what the TDF needed. Lacking the resources to turn the newly redesigned Talos into a viable production model, the Taurians enlisted the aid of their neighbours, in exchange for joining the ongoing Trinity Alliance negotiations. Aided by the expertise of Capellan engineers and financial investment from the Magistracy of Canopus, Vandenburg started limited manufacturing of the Talos; at their New Vandenburg plant: in late 3059. The formal signing of the Trinity Alliance, in 3062; awarded production licenses to both Majesty Metals and Detroit Consolidated Mech Works. Both companies swiftly opened their own lines, producing multiple variants of the Talos for their own use and for export further afield. Quirk: Easy to Pilot Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.04

Arm Actuator Limit: Right Lower

name: Talos TLS-4B
details:
With the reintroduction of Helm Core LosTech, the Taurian Defense Force found themselves lagging behind their neighbours. Just as they did during the Age of War, the Taurians turned to the home grown Talos. With a reputation as an easy to maintain and easy to manufacture mech, the design was just what the TDF needed. Lacking the resources to turn the newly redesigned Talos into a viable production model, the Taurians enlisted the aid of their neighbours, in exchange for joining the ongoing Trinity Alliance negotiations. Aided by the expertise of Capellan engineers and financial investment from the Magistracy of Canopus, Vandenburg started limited manufacturing of the Talos; at their New Vandenburg plant: in late 3059. The formal signing of the Trinity Alliance, in 3062; awarded production licenses to both Majesty Metals and Detroit Consolidated Mech Works. Both companies swiftly opened their own lines, producing multiple variants of the Talos for their own use and for export further afield. Quirk: Easy to Pilot Drop Cost Multiplier: 1.04

Arm Actuator Limit: Right Lower

name: Tarantula ZPH-1
details: The original variant of the Tarantula is armored with four and a half tons of armor, while it only carries about three quarters of the theoretical maximum armor, the 'Mech's amazing speed makes the Tarantula capable of avoiding most damage. As the design is focused on scouting, the Tarantula carries a light armament that is common to a 'Mech of its size and role. The primary weapons are a pair of medium lasers which give the Tarantula most of its striking power. These are backed up by a Streak SRM-2 launcher, which allows the Tarantula to find any weak spots in an enemy's armor. Quirk: Easy to Pilot Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.98

name: Tarantula ZPH-2A
details: The 2A variant is a simple upgrade of the Tarantula that brings the 'Mechs weapons up to current standards. This is done by replacing the two medium lasers with a pair of ER medium lasers. Quirk: Easy to Pilot Drop Cost Multiplier: 0.98

name: Tarantula ZPH-2C
